title: Health tourism blamed for poor NHS treatment by majority of Brits
text:

More than two thirds of Britons blame health tourism by overseas visitors for their poor NHS treatment. 
An exclusive ComRes poll for the Sunday Mirror shows 68 per cent of those questioned think the use of the health service by foreigners reduces the quality of care for British taxpayers. 
Only one in five reckon it makes no difference. 
One in three patients say they would be prepared to pay to jump the queue for NHS treatment but half would not dip into their own pockets. 
Meanwhile on other issues of the day 45 per cent say Commons Speaker John Bercow was right to try to ban Donald Trump from Parliament - though 47 per cent of voters were happy for the US president to meet the Queen when he visits Britain. 
More than half of Britons are against Mr Trump’s travel ban for Muslim countries and 55 per cent would not want to see one imposed here. 
Labour voters are split on whether Labour MPs were right to vote against Article 50 triggering Brexit . Read More A&E crisis exposed as only three out of 139 health trusts achieved A&E waiting time targets Most people believe John Bercow was right to ban Donald Trump (Photo: PA) 
Nearly half say that Labour should not try to block our EU exit though a significant 39 per cent minority disagree. 
But four in ten of all voters say that the British economy will perform better once Article 50 is triggered. 
Theresa May emerges as more popular than David Beckham after the soccer star’s anger at not getting an honour were revealed in leaked emails. 
More than four in ten have a favourable view of the PM compared to 37 per cent for Beckham. 
Twice as many of those questioned took against John Bercow than those who have a favourable view - 30-15 per cent. 
But he is a point ahead of Donald Trump on 14 per cent, while Lib Dem leader Tim Farron scores 11 per cent and Russia’s Vladimir Putin seven per cent. 
Jeremy Corbyn ’s favourability ratings have dropped four points since December to 20 per cent - two points below Nigel Farage. 
And things are not looking much better for Labour when it comes to voting intentions. 
The party is on just 26 per cent, 15 points behind the Tories on 41 per cent. Con 41%
